title.narrative: Economic Development and Job Creation in the Dairy Sector

description.narrative: The Projects seeks to create jobs and economic developoment in the dairy sector in Tunisia by 1) improving the regulatory and political framework, 2) improving the quality and quantity of the milk procudtion and 3) developing SMEs within the sector.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation

title.narrative: 1. Improve the Political and Regulatory Framework

It is important to have an overall political framework and strategic framework in place for developing the dairy sector. Phase 2 of the project includes setting up a twinning arrangement between the Danish and Tunisian authorities, the DVFA and OEP. The aim of this arrangement is to identify the framework conditions hampering development of the dairy sector. By drawing on Denmark’s experience, the capacities of the stakeholders involved will be improved and solutions developed for further enhancing the dairy sector in Tunisia. The DVFA can contribute by providing technical assistance and by improving understanding of how agricultural policies, including subsidy schemes, are implemented in Denmark.
3. Promote Specialisation and Diversification in Béja

The project will support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) working in the milk processing and marketing sector and/or service providers and input suppliers within the value chain. Two areas of activity have been identified for promoting specialisation and diversification:
2. Improve the Quantity & Quality of Milk in Béja

The poor quality of raw milk and low productivity at the farm have been identified as major constraints within the dairy value chain. This component will address these constraints by launching a series of activities to improve productivity, focusing both on the quantity and quality of the milk produced. The quality of raw milk at the farm is the starting point for a productive dairy sector. Once compromised, it is not possible to improve the quality of this milk further along the value chain. Four areas of activity have been identified to address the constraints associated with the poor quality of milk.
Activity Area 2.3. Set up a working payment system

Activity 2.3.1. Mobilising stakeholders and instilling confidence Activity 2.3.2. Conducting a situation analysis and developing the payment system Activity 2.3.3. Delivering technical training to the people involved Activity 2.3.4. Piloting and expanding the quality-based payment system
Activity Area 2.4. Improve coordination within the value chain

Activity 2.4.1. Facilitating the Dairy Value Chain Forum Activity 2.4.2. Sharing information and communications on decisions made by the Forum and their implementation status and also on the status of the Forum an officially recognised joint trade organisation Activity 2.4.3. Conducting studies and research & development activities Activity 2.4.4. Strengthening contractual relationships between value chain stakeholders Activity 2.4.5. Developing the capacities of value chain organisations Activity 2.4.6. Supporting the OEP laboratory to become the arbitrating laboratory
Activity Area 3.1. Promote semi-industrial dairies

Activity 3.1.1. Creating a pilot cheese-making plant Activity 3.1.2. Conducting studies on the cheese sector and market potential Activity 3.1.3. Supporting the development of business plans Activity 3.1.4. Providing training on cheese-making good practice and processing techniques Activity 3.1.5. Providing business management (business plans, feasibility assessments and financial analyses, etc.) and SME management training Activity 3.1.6. Developing the supply chain Activity 3.1.7. Developing milk quality management control systems Activity 3.1.8. Supporting access to finance for semi-industrial dairies (see Annex 5) Activity 3.1.9. Creating a coaching plan to help dairy farmers implement their projects (management, animal feed and husbandry training)
1.2. Improve standards and the monitoring system

As part of efforts to improve the quality of raw milk, it is important to set up effective management and monitoring mechanisms and ensure that the relevant standards for milk and dairy products are applied. More specifically, the work to be carried out will involve: i) developing and revising standards to ensure they are aligned to international standards (for food safety and traceability, for example); and ii) building management and monitoring mechanism capacities. It would also be particularly useful to review / align standards with those required for exports.
Activity 1.2.1. Developing and revising standards Activity 1.2.2. Improving management and monitoring mechanisms and principles
1.1 Revise dairy strategies and policies

The Tunisian government provides a raft of subsidies to the dairy sector. It is therefore necessary to assess how these substantial resources can be best used to maximise their impact on development. In concrete terms, this will involve conducting an analysis to determine how investment can be promoted and identify the most profitable way of reducing the imbalance between seasonal production and demand. The project will particularly focus on climate change and the environment. Work is currently underway in Tunisia to identify and address climate change-related issues. Agriculture has been identified as an important factor. As part of this project, efforts will be undertaken to tie dairy sector priorities and tangible actions in Béja into the national programme to tackle climate change.
Activity 1.1.1. Streamlining the regulatory framework Activity 1.1.2. Optimising the impact of subsidies Activity 1.1.3. Improving the dairy sector strategic framework
Activity Area 2.1. Improve agricultural productivity

The activities here include: Activity 2.1.1. Building technical capacities and providing technical support Activity 2.1.2. Providing business management training (business plans, feasibility assessments and financial analyses, etc.) Activity 2.1.3. Supporting access to finance for dairy farmers (see Annex 5) Activity 2.1.4. Improving advisory services for dairy farmers (public and private) (including building the OEP’s logistical capacities as the main agricultural advisory service)
Activity Area 2.2. Improve the dairy cold chain

The activities here include: Activity 2.2.1. Delivering technical training to milk collection centre staff and transporters Activity 2.2.2. Providing business management training (business plans, feasibility assessments and financial analyses, etc.) Activity 2.2.3. Promoting access to finance for milk collection centres and transporters (see Annex 5) Activity 2.2.4. Developing cooperative milk cooling centres
Activity Area 3.2. Promote SMEs supplying inputs and services

The associated activities include: Activity 3.2.1. Conducting studies on the types of input potentially required (silage, equipment, fertiliser, etc.) Activity 3.2.2. Delivering awareness-raising and training sessions to share information on the latest technological trends and SME project support processes Activity 3.2.3. Developing business plans for SMEs supplying inputs to the dairy sector Activity 3.2.4. Providing business management (business plans, feasibility assessments and financial analyses, etc.) Activity 3.2.5. Supporting access to finance for SMEs providing inputs and support (see Annex 5) Activity 3.2.6. Creating a coaching plan to help SMEs implement their projects (management training, production monitoring, etc.)
